Award.AwardTitle: Control of Dynamic Patterns in Neuronal Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The past decade has seen significant growth in the development and use of neurostimulation technology to manipulate neural activity in the brain. The applications of such technology range from scientific objectives, e.g., studying how different parts of the brain interact with each other, to clinical objectives, e.g., using stimulation to alleviate the symptoms of neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease. Despite many technological advances associated with such stimulation, its use is still largely limited to perturbative paradigms, in which stereotyped inputs (waveforms) are used to activate or deactivate a neuronal network in its entirety. In other words, the stimulation is used to create a uniform circuit response, turning an entire population of brain cells (neurons) on or off, without regard for specificity (i.e., which cells in the population respond) or timing (i.e., when they turn on or off). In engineering, control is understood as not simply uniform stimulation, but as the precise creation or prevention of certain system maneuvers at each moment in time. This project will investigate fundamental questions regarding the use of neurostimulation to control neuronal networks in this temporally precise sense. That is, rather than simply stimulating the brain, the goal of this research is to develop new engineering theory and methods to allow practitioners to steer the activity in neural circuits so as to create complex patterns of activity, or neural spiking. Thus, this highly transdisciplinary project will elucidate enabling theory for the use of neurostimulation and will lead to new and fundamental contributions to systems theory and control engineering. The project will also support new initiatives to promote interdisciplinary education for students from traditionally underserved populations through the creation of summer workshops for students from local high schools in the city of St. Louis, MO.

By bridging ensemble systems theory with computational neuroscience, general and versatile frameworks for neuronal control will be formulated. Specifically, oscillator and conductance-based neural models will be used to mathematically model both oscillatory and non-oscillatory regimes in brain networks. Using these models, the proposed work will determine fundamental limits on the controllability of neuronal spiking or synchronization by the application of external inputs. The notion of ensemble reachability is also proposed and will be examined via entropic gain analysis and dynamic optimization. These characterizations of fundamental control properties in both oscillatory and non-oscillatory neural dynamic regimes will then facilitate the development of control design paradigms to synthesize optimal controls for the creation of complex patterns in neuronal populations, such as firing or entrainment patterns. Methods of ensemble control and formal averaging will be employed to derive optimal sequence and pattern controls, and stochastic versions of these problems will also be treated using stochastic control techniques to ensure tolerance to noise and uncertainty, which are pervasive in neural circuits. Thus, the results of the proposed research will include a unified systems-theoretic framework for analyzing the control of physiologically relevant brain networks; and further, will include a set of formal neural control design methods that may be readily translated to a range of neurostimulation implementations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The past decade has seen significant growth in the development and use of neurostimulation technology to manipulate neural activity in the brain. The applications of such technology range from scientific objectives, e.g., studying how different parts of the brain interact with each other, to clinical objectives, e.g., using stimulation to alleviate the symptoms of neurological disorders such as Parkinson?s disease. While such stimulation is widely used in experimental neuroscience and in brain medicine, its use is largely limited to activating or deactivating the underlying network in its entirety, without regard to specificity (i.e., which cells in the population respond) or timing (i.e., when they turn on or off). This project develops a principled systems theory for using these devices to `control' neural activity with fine spatial and temporal precision and leads to new control-theoretic formulations that meet the unique challenges of modeling and controlling activity in neuronal networks.

By bridging ensemble systems theory with computational neuroscience, general and versatile frameworks for neuronal control have been formulated. This highly transdisciplinary project has elucidated enabling theory, derived from rigorous mathematical control and systems theory, for the use of neurostimulation in basic science and clinical applications. Specifically, oscillator and conductance-based neural models were used to determine fundamental limits on the controllability of neuronal spiking or synchronization by the application of external inputs. This characterization of control properties in both oscillatory and non-oscillatory dynamical regimes facilitated the development of control design paradigms to synthesize optimal controls for creating desired firing patterns. Techniques of ensemble control and high-dimensional optimization were employed to derive optimal sequence and pattern controls, and stochastic versions of these problems were also treated using stochastic control techniques to ensure tolerance to noise and uncertainty, which are pervasive in neural circuits. In addition, operator-theoretic data-driven methods were developed for extracting dynamics or dynamic behaviors of a complex neuronal system from its measurement data and for dimensionality reduction. Learning approaches were also developed to induce patterns of spiking activity in neuronal networks. Accompanying these control synthesis techniques was the development of new model fitting and system identification frameworks for obtaining dynamical models of spiking neurons and networks thereof. The project outcomes enabled a unified systems-theoretic framework for analyzing the control of physiologically relevant brain networks, and, further, include a set of formal neural control design methods that may be readily translated to a range of neurostimulation implementations.

This project substantially advances our understanding of dynamic complex networks that are ubiquitous in nature, and contributes to computational optimal control, ensemble systems theory, computational neuroscience, and brain medicine by investigating nonconventional control engineering problems related to neural stimulation. Advanced methods for optimal stimulation design may potentially lead to innovative techniques for clinical neural engineering, such as deep brain stimulation, and facilitate improved design of other neuronal stimulation modalities such as optogenetics. The project also enhances the infrastructure for research and education across these disciplines by merging the fields of control theory, dynamical systems and computational neuroscience. The research products and outcomes have been disseminated broadly to these scientific communities through publications, presentations at conferences, invited lectures and colloquia, and distributed software to engage researchers around the world in this exciting new domain. 

Multiple workshops, including the Midwest Workshop on Control and Game Theory, workshops on `Systems Theory, Mathematics, and Neuroscience' and on `Advanced Data-driven Methods for Complex Systems Analysis and Controls' were organized and concerted effort were made by the PIs to attract under-represented minorities and women to our research program. An independent study course on `Neural control and engineering with clinical applications' was established by the co-PIs. The outreach effort was continued made to engage the general public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through Science Outreach Programs at Washington University in St. Louis.
